name: Ethosuximide (Zarontin)
summary: An anticonvulsant primarily used for the treatment of absence seizures.
description: Ethosuximide is a succinimide anticonvulsant that works by reducing T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons, thereby stabilizing neuronal activity and preventing the abnormal cortical rhythms seen in absence seizures. It is considered the drug of choice for uncomplicated absence epilepsy.

sections.text: Reduces low-threshold T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons, suppressing the rhythmic cortical discharges characteristic of absence seizures.

adult.absence_seizures: Initial: 500 mg/day; may increase by 250 mg every 4–7 days; usual maintenance: 1–1.5 g/day in 1–2 divided doses

sections.pediatric: Initial: 250 mg/day; increase by 250 mg every 4–7 days; usual maintenance: 20 mg/kg/day in divided doses

sections.text: Onset within several days to weeks; duration of action is 24 hours (once-daily dosing possible).

other: Monitor for behavioral and mood changes
Use caution in patients with liver or kidney disease

items.risk: Altered serum levels of both drugs

sections.pregnancy: Use if benefits outweigh risks; risk of teratogenicity
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: No specific adjustments, but monitor organ function

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over several weeks to avoid seizure recurrence.

items: Most effective monotherapy for absence seizures
Less sedating than some other antiepileptics
Gastrointestinal side effects can be minimized by dividing doses or taking with food

seo.title: Ethosuximide (Zarontin): Anticonvulsant for Absence Seizures
seo.description: Ethosuximide (Zarontin) is an anticonvulsant used primarily for the treatment of absence seizures, acting via T-type calcium channel blockade.
